title: The impact of the early environment on oxytocin receptor epigenetics and potential therapeutic implications
affiliations: Department of Neurology, University of Virginia, Charlottesville, VA, USA
Department of Pediatrics, Division of Neonatology, University of Virginia, Charlottesville, VA, USA
background: Oxytocin's role in social behavior and psychopathology is increasingly understood through epigenetic modifications to the oxytocin receptor gene (OXTR).
hypotheses: Early life environment shapes OXTR epigenetics and impacts social-developmental outcomes.
OXTR methylation (OXTRm) serves as a predictive mechanism for neurodevelopmental outcomes.
OXTRm can serve as a powerful therapeutic target to improve oxytocin therapeutics.
major_findings: Early life experiences, such as maternal care, significantly impact OXTRm in both animal models and humans.
OXTRm is a reliable predictor of neurodevelopmental outcomes, including social behavior and psychopathology.
Specific CpG sites within the OXTR gene show functional associations between methylation and gene expression.
OXTRm may impact additional cellular mechanisms, such as the perinatal GABA switch, with therapeutic potential.
Early life therapies targeting OXTRm may improve the therapeutic potential of exogenous oxytocin.
